start.instruction: To set up your ODrive, connect it and power it up.
start.troubleshoot: Having trouble? Click here for debug output

brake.title: Brake Resistor
brake.noBrake: I don't have a brake resistor

motor.title: Which motor are you using on Axis {axis}?

encoder.title: Which encoder are you using for Axis {axis}?

choices.noBrakeResistor: I don't have a brake resistor

tooltips.brakeResistor: When you slow down a motor, the energy has to go somewhere. It either goes to the brake resistor or back to your power supply.
tooltips.noBrake: Only operate without a brake resistor if your power source can handle reverse current, like a battery.
tooltips.motorCal: ODrive needs to know the inductance and resistance of your motor in order to control it. Click the Calibrate Motor button to start the measurement process. The motor will beep during calibration.
tooltips.motorCalNext: ODrive needs to know the inductance and resistance of your motor in order to control it. Click the Calibrate Motor button to start the measurement process. The motor will beep during calibration.
tooltips.d5065: D5065 motor from the ODrive shop
tooltips.d6374: D6374 motor from the ODrive shop
tooltips.cuiEncoder: Incremental 8192cpr encoder from the ODrive shop
tooltips.hallEffect: If your motor is 'sensored' and you don't have another encoder, select this option
tooltips.incrementalNoIndex: Generic incremental encoder without index. Set cpr to 4 * PPR (pulses per revolution).
tooltips.incrementalWithIndex: Generic incremental encoder with index. Set cpr to 4 * PPR (pulses per revolution).
tooltips.encoderCalNext: ODrive needs to know the relation between the encoder position and motor position in order to function. Click the Calibrate Encoder button to start the measurement process. The motor will slowly rotate back and forth during calibration.
tooltips.motorCalFail: Double check your motor connections. If the connections are good, it is possible that your motor has a higher resistance or lower inductance than ODrive expects.
tooltips.encoderCalFail: Double check your encoder connections. If the connections are good, you have a wrong setting for motor pole pairs or encoder cpr.
